The Health Professions
Recommendations Committee has been
streamlined to facilitate appraisal of
students applying • to post-graduate
"health" schools, such as medical, dental,
and public health schools.
Committee chairman John W. Gryder

been implemented during 'the tenure of
his predecessor, the late Dr. Matthew
Debuskey. Basically, Gryder explained,
the number of committee members has
been reduced from about twenty to
eleven. The rationale for the size
reduction was to increase each
recommender's exposure to the
graduating class, enabling the professor
not only to evaluate the individual on
personal merits, but to emphasize those
aspects of the student's background
which would improve the applicant's
chances of admission. "We want to be as
positive as possible, without lying," said
Gryder. With a working knowledge of the
level of competetition a candidate is
likely to encounter, the recommending
professor can find "some reason why the
graduate school might want to accept the
student," Gryder pointed out.

Rene Levesque, the controversial Quebec Premier, ran
into a small problem this weekend. To be more precise he
ran over an unidentified man lying in the road. Avoiding
a
man parked by the roadside, Levesque swerved to the
left
and drove over the body. The Premier stated that
he
believed the man was dead before the accident took place.
After a few hours at the local police station, he was release
d
without any charges filed against him.

•
It all sounds like good material for a political mystery: a
rising leader, headed toward an independent
French-Canadian nation, involved in a bizarre accident with
a stranger and unknown body. Levesque's opponents will
press the scandal on him for political leverage; the press will
naturally send out its crack investigators to unearth the
sinister details. The forthcoming reams of copy and barbed
words will link Levesque's personal problems with his work
as Premier. It is unfortunate that the recent rash of scandals
may push people into a blind hole and obscure or blur their
vision of Levesque's program. Restraint in the middle of a
revolution would be welcome.

movies and books that move people to a
new consciousness of the forces that
shape our lives that are
political. The much more numerous and
pervasive cultural phenomena that
discreetly immobilize us and impede such
an understanding are equally political.

In a recent editorial, the Sun stated
that the television dramatization of Alex
Haley's novel "Roots" was "political."
Indeed, it called the showing "a

true. But the clear implication of so
characterizing "Roofs" seems to be that
what we normally experience in the mass
media and in our educational system is
somehow not, or less, "political."
If. however, "Roots" has "taught or
reminded" us of "the heart of the
American experience" and if "the
deficiencies of our educational system
and the mind-debilitating lure of the junk
that TV offers" has meant, as you
correctly claim, that "millions of
Americans...do not adequately know and
therefore do not adequately feel the
forces that shaped (and continue to
shape) our society," then must it not
follow our daily run-of-the-mill culture is
also profoundly, if normally less
obviously, "political?"
Whatever may be intended, our culture
in so many ways tends to rniseducate,
distract and pacify -us about ourselves and
the forces that shape our lives.
Is it not, for example, extremely
political to portray working class people
as quaintly mindless boobs, as so much of
TV does? Was it apolitical for the
immortal "I Love Lucy" to show women
primarily as purposeless digbats? Is
"Gone with the Wind," the media event•
with which "Roots" most frequently is
being compared, really less political?
My understanding is that all of these
are political, although the content and
visibility of the politics may differ from
case to case.
It is not only the handful of TV shows,
movies and books that move people to a
new consciousness of the forces that
shape our lives that are
political. The much more numerous and
pervasive cultural phenomena that
discreetly immobilize us and impede such
an understanding are equally political.
